segment.source: Simulate a Windows 10 deployment in a test environment (Windows 10)
segment.target: Simulate a Windows 10 deployment in a test environment (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic will walk you through the process of creating a simulated environment on which to test your Windows 10 deployment using MDT.
segment.target: This topic will walk you through the process of creating a simulated environment on which to test your Windows 10 deployment using MDT.

segment.source: Simulate a Windows 10 deployment in a test environment
segment.target: Simulate a Windows 10 deployment in a test environment

segment.source: This topic will walk you through the process of creating a simulated environment on which to test your Windows 10 deployment using MDT.
segment.target: This topic will walk you through the process of creating a simulated environment on which to test your Windows 10 deployment using MDT.

segment.source: When working with advanced settings and rules, especially those like database calls, it is most efficient to be able to test the settings without having to run through a complete deployment.
segment.target: When working with advanced settings and rules, especially those like database calls, it is most efficient to be able to test the settings without having to run through a complete deployment.

segment.source: Luckily, MDT enables you to perform a simulated deployment by running the Gather process by itself.
segment.target: Luckily, MDT enables you to perform a simulated deployment by running the Gather process by itself.

segment.source: The simulation works best when you are using a domain-joined machine (client or server).
segment.target: The simulation works best when you are using a domain-joined machine (client or server).

segment.source: In the following example, you use the PC0001 Windows 10 client.
segment.target: In the following example, you use the PC0001 Windows 10 client.

segment.source: For the purposes of this topic, you already will have either downloaded and installed the free Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager Toolkit, or copied Configuration Manager Trace (CMTrace) if you have access to the System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager media.
segment.target: For the purposes of this topic, you already will have either downloaded and installed the free Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager Toolkit, or copied Configuration Manager Trace (CMTrace) if you have access to the System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager media.

segment.source: We also assume that you have downloaded the sample Gather.ps1 script from the TechNet gallery.
segment.target: We also assume that you have downloaded the sample Gather.ps1 script from the TechNet gallery.

segment.source: On PC0001, log on as CONTOSOAdministrator using the password P@ssw0rd.
segment.target: On PC0001, log on as CONTOSOAdministrator using the password P@ssw0rd.

segment.source: Using Computer Management, add the CONTOSOMDTBA user account to the local Administrators group.
segment.target: Using Computer Management, add the CONTOSOMDTBA user account to the local Administrators group.

segment.source: Log off, and then log on to PC0001 as CONTOSOMDTBA.
segment.target: Log off, and then log on to PC0001 as CONTOSOMDTBA.

segment.source: Using File Explorer, create a folder named C:MDT.
segment.target: Using File Explorer, create a folder named C:MDT.

segment.source: Copy the downloaded Gather.ps1 script to the C:MDT folder.
segment.target: Copy the downloaded Gather.ps1 script to the C:MDT folder.

segment.source: From the MDT01MDTProduction$Scripts folder, copy the following files to C:MDT:
segment.target: From the MDT01MDTProduction$Scripts folder, copy the following files to C:MDT:

segment.source: ZTIDataAccess.vbs
segment.target: ZTIDataAccess.vbs

segment.source: ZTIGather.wsf
segment.target: ZTIGather.wsf

segment.source: ZTIGather.xml
segment.target: ZTIGather.xml

segment.source: ZTIUtility.vbs
segment.target: ZTIUtility.vbs

segment.source: From the MDT01MDTProduction$Control folder, copy the CustomSettings.ini file to C:MDT.
segment.target: From the MDT01MDTProduction$Control folder, copy the CustomSettings.ini file to C:MDT.

segment.source: In the C:MDT folder, create a subfolder named X64.
segment.target: In the C:MDT folder, create a subfolder named X64.

segment.source: From the MDT01MDTProduction$ToolsX64 folder, copy the Microsoft.BDD.Utility.dll file to C:MDTX64.
segment.target: From the MDT01MDTProduction$ToolsX64 folder, copy the Microsoft.BDD.Utility.dll file to C:MDTX64.

segment.source: figure 6
segment.target: figure 6

segment.source: Figure 6.
segment.target: Figure 6.

segment.source: The C:MDT folder with the files added for the simulation environment.
segment.target: The C:MDT folder with the files added for the simulation environment.

segment.source: Using an elevated Windows PowerShell prompt (run as Administrator), run the following commands.
segment.target: Using an elevated Windows PowerShell prompt (run as Administrator), run the following commands.

segment.source: Press Enter after each command:
segment.target: Press Enter after each command:

segment.source: Review the ZTIGather.log in the C:MININTSMSOSDOSDLOGS folder.
segment.target: Review the ZTIGather.log in the C:MININTSMSOSDOSDLOGS folder.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Warnings or errors with regard to the Wizard.hta are expected.
segment.target: Warnings or errors with regard to the Wizard.hta are expected.

segment.source: If the log file looks okay, you are ready to try a real deployment.
segment.target: If the log file looks okay, you are ready to try a real deployment.

segment.target: figure 7

segment.target: Figure 7.

segment.target: The ZTIGather.log file from PC0001, displaying some of its hardware capabilities.
